For some reason, WordPress suspended my coding blog in December. There was a link to a message in my dashboard that was supposed to have details, but it just took […]

posts.title: November 2023 Update
posts.content:
It’s been 10 months since I last posted, so I’m long overdue with an update.

Scrimba

In the time that’s passed, I’ve come very close to completing Scrimba’s Frontend Developer Path. I’m on the module right before the final one, Advanced React. I effectively have 1.5 modules left to finish before I’m done with it and can get the certificate. It’s taken me longer than I anticipated to finish the material because I’ve built a lot of personal projects while working through the curriculum. That’s the best way to learn. Family obligations also took time away from Scrimba, sometimes for weeks at a time.

100Devs Huntober

I paused Scrimba at the beginning of October to join 100Devs‘ #Huntober event. It’s open to people who haven’t completed 100Devs’ bootcamp. Currently, we’re in week 6 of it. Leon Noel, who runs 100Devs, decided to extend it for a few weeks because there’s material that he wants to share with the cohort that we didn’t cover in the scheduled month.

I’m really impressed with Huntober. The approach is completely different from Lambda‘s (now BloomTech). It’s extremely people-focused. Apart from learning how to code, Leon mandates that people in each cohort network. The biggest thing that he preaches is networking. You’re told to compile a list (called your Hit List) of 60 companies that you want to work with. For each of those companies, you have to network with 3 people who work there. And it’s not just sending a LinkedIn connection request and calling it a day if they accept it. You have to reach out to people at those companies, and at other spaces – engineers, hiring managers, people who you find interesting – and you build relationships. Chat with them. Get to know them. Become their friends. Show genuine interest in their lives.

The idea is that people hire people who they like, which makes a lot of sense. Leon has said that it’s generally believed that the tech industry is a meritocracy. It’s not. It’s nepotistic, like everything else. It doesn’t matter how skilled a person is at writing code and solving algorithmic problems. If you don’t know people and they don’t like you and have an interest in helping you succeed, you’re not going to get the jobs that you want. So, network your way into the position that you’re after.

Leon shares resources and gives advice on how to go about doing this constantly. Throughout Huntober, we did things that I hadn’t done at Lambda. We crafted a story about ourselves. It tells potential employers who we are and what we can bring to their company. We’re encouraged to explain how we’re the hero of our story. That story can become the summary on your resume, can go on your LinkedIn profile and becomes your elevator pitch. It’s not something I’d ever done before, and it was amazing to hear him talk to people who had little experience, no college degree, were career changers, thought that their experience wasn’t transferrable to developer roles and who were simply not confident with themselves. There were single mothers and people who had been out of the workforce for years and others who thought that they were ill-fits for software engineer roles. He spun their experiences into jaw-dropping stories. I wish we could have recorded them.

After stories have been crafted, he has us work on our resumes using a format that he recommends that does well against ATS (applicant tracking software) and guides recruiters to the most salient information about us in the average 7 seconds that they spend glancing at our resumes. He talks about how to pass the “sniff test” to get sent to the next stage of interviews. Apart from format, there were a lot of tips shared about crafting resume bullets, and he frequently let people from the audience join him onstage and reviewed their resumes in real time, offering suggestions, criticisms and praise where warranted.

We started incorporating code challenges into the daily meetings. Some are an hour long, and others are 30 minutes. Sometimes, they stretch past the time that they were supposed to end. There are guest appearances by other speakers who are in the industry and who want to offer advice. This coming week, we’re going to focus on LinkedIn and get tips for building and fine-tuning our profiles.

Huntober is motivating. Leon talks to a lot of people with every session. He helps people with interview tips, with negotiating job offers and with other concerns that they’ve come across – like one woman who found herself getting solicited for dating by interviewers while out with them, which apparently has happened to several others who attended the meeting. He gives responses and ideas to a lot of different scenarios and is a font of knowledge about networking and building relationships that can be mined for job referrals. There’s salary negotiation advice, information about how to gain perks at different companies, and approaches on how to learn what will be asked by specific companies during different kinds of interviews – like behavioral or technical ones.

I plan on joining the #catch-up-crew at 100Devs and working through the material as much as I can, and then joining their next cohort in January 2024. There are a lot of other initiatives moving forward at the bootcamp – which is completely free. It’s simply amazing. I wish I had taken time to learn more about it and join it sooner.

Later this month, after Huntober ends, Leon is running a free crash course or bootcamp focused on freelancing. I look forward to that, because I’m certain it’ll give me insight into how to better run my freelancing LLC.

Tailwind

This month, I started learning Tailwind CSS. I just completed my first project with it yesterday, based on a crash course from Brad Traversy. It got me acquainted with the syntax for the system as well as how to set it up so that it can be used in a project and how to add my own CSS and my own customizations to the setup. My goal is to build at least one project every week with Tailwind, to really get hands-on experience using it. Then, I plan on redesigning both my portfolio and my LLC’s website and rebuilding them both using Tailwind alongside any custom CSS that I might need.

Unlike a lot of other developers, I actually like CSS. Switching from CSS to Tailwind is interesting to me because it works differently from how I’m used to working. I tend to follow the idea of “separation of concerns” when I build web projects. One requirement of this is that HTML and CSS go into their own, separate files. Tailwind does away with this by adding utility classes directly in HTML. Those classes equate to CSS. You’re not actually writing CSS. That gets generated by Tailwind in it’s own file, but your HTML elements often have lengthy strings of class names attached to them that correspond with individual CSS properties.

Initially, the thought of this left a bad taste in my mouth, but after even this first project, I find that I can live with it. I’m interested in seeing how I feel about this at the end of the month, after gaining more experience with the system.

Networking

Last month, I went to my first in-person programmer meetup in Koreatown, in Los Angeles. I brought my friend Sue with me. We met members of Learn Teach Code LA at a restaurant called Anju House and spent around 5 or 6 hours talking to everyone. It was a lot of fun learning about everyone’s backgrounds and seeing who was working and who was on the job hunt and what brought them into tech. Anju House’s musubi appetizers are fantastic. You get 8 pieces for $10, and there’s enough in one order to feed both of my kids. We shared a pitcher of soju (mixed with some yogurt) which definitely played a part in making us more social and getting others at the table to talk. I joined their Discord earlier this week and plan on going back when I’m free. Several of the people at the table ended up connecting with me on LinkedIn and Instagram, and I’ve been chatting with some of them since.

In-person networking seems to be effective, and it’s fun, too. I know some people have anxiety about meeting others, both online and in the flesh, but I think that the right group of people can really help alleviate the nervousness associated with that. This group is one of them. There were some really insightful people, as well as people who were less knowledgeable about certain things, but the overall exchange was really fun.

I’ve also been connecting with people from both Scrimba and 100Devs recently. With Scrimba, it’s been since January. With 100Devs, it’s only been about a week, but the chats that I’m having with these people have been pretty involved, so it takes some effort, but I find their stories interesting. Some of them live in or come from areas that are much more strife-ridden than where I’m from. A few have learned more about me and what happened in my life since coming to California. I’ve come to appreciate talking to them. It’s both therapeutic and mind-expanding.

Yesterday, I created a Discord server that I want to use to help people who are on the job hunt for a role in tech. I’ll probably start inviting people to it over the next few days. I plan on keeping it small, so we can stay very focused, but over time, I’ll grow it.

There’s a lot of other stuff going on that I can’t get into detail about, but I’ve helped people set up a business recently and it’s doing really well. I’ve been keeping busy with a group of people who I meet with regularly during the week to help with some things that are both work-related and non-work-related. My girls both leveled up – one is 11 years old now and the other turned 6 right before Halloween. We have a bunch of guests rotating in for the holidays, and the job market is finally starting to pick up a bit again for tech workers.

There are dozens of things I want to write about in upcoming blog posts, but it’s been really hard to find time to do it. Hopefully, I’ll be able to more frequently.

posts.title: JavaScript’s Date(), setInterval() and .style property
posts.content:
The clock project from JavaScript30 made use of several CSS properties and JavaScript methods that I’ve used infrequently in other projects. When I was building out the project and then adding onto it after, I ended up delving into their documentation to understand how they operate. This is some of what I learned:

Date()

The Date() constructor creates a new Date object representing a single moment in time. When called without any arguments, it returns the current date and time. Initially, we use it to get a new date value and save it to a const:

const now = new Date()

As of the time of this writing, that code returns: Fri Jan 13 2023 00:10:50 GMT-0800 (Pacific Standard Time). It’s Friday the 13th! From there, in order to position the clock hands, we created new variables to store the date’s seconds, minutes and hours. This information was extracted with methods attached to the Date() object:

const seconds = now.getSeconds()
const mins = now.getMinutes()
const hours = now.getHours()

I used the data returned from that to position the analog clock hands and to render the time using numbers in the digital clock that I added to the bottom of the project. In addition to that, I used several other methods to get the calendar date, which I appended below the digital clock:

const month = now.getMonth()
const date = now.getDate()
const year = now.getFullYear()

I had to massage the values returned by these methods a little before rendering them onscreen by creating functions to format the time, day and month. For time, I wrote a function that appended a “0” to an hour, minute or second if it was less than 10, so that my digital clock used two digits for each field. I used that same function on the date in the calendar date.

I wrote another function that converted 24-hour time to 12-hour time for the digital clock. The .hours() method returns a value from 0 – 23. To correct this, just subtract 12 from any value greater than 12.

My last two formatting functions translated the day of the week and the month from numbers into names. For example “0” becomes “Sun”, “1” becomes “Mon” and so on for the days of the week and “0” becomes “Jan”, “1” becomes “Feb” and so on for the month.

  • MDN: Date
  • MDN: Date() constructor
  • w3schools: JavaScript Date Reference
  • w3schools: JavaScript Date Objects

setInterval()

setInterval() is a method that repeatedly calls a function or evaluates an expression at specified intervals (in milliseconds). This was the main execution code in the clock application. After setting up the functions that got the Date() and set its returned data into individual variables and formatted them, setInterval() called the function that makes everything go once every second. It looked like this:

setInterval(setDate, 1000)

1,000 milliseconds is equal to 1 second, so it essentially caused the program to re-render every second with a new Date() and its extracted values. This was the little engine that could.

  • MDN: setInterval()
  • w3schools: Window setInterval() method

element.style.transform()

Finally, we have the .style.transform() method. This is essentially the JavaScript way of modifying the CSS transform property on an HTML element. .style essentially holds all of the properties available in CSS to style HTML elements. The one that we focused on during this project was:

element.style.transform = `rotate(${someValue}deg)`

For example, to change the seconds hand, I used:

secondHand.style.transform = `rotate(${secondsDegrees}deg)`

setInterval() saw to it that the value was refreshed every second (as were all of the other date values, so the minutes and hours were refreshed as well, as were even longer-lasting parts of Date() like the day, month and year) and used to determine the angle to position each clock hand on the clock face. Only the seconds hand actually moved every second. The data for the other hands refreshed, but their position changed at their own intervals (every minute and every hour – surprise!).

The main .transform property that we adjusted was the rotate() property, but other .transform properties and other .style properties, like .transition, were also used in the actual CSS for the project. I’ll discuss the CSS in another post, including the .transform from here, because although we’re using JavaScript to update the property data, it’s better grouped together as its own post (separation of concerns strikes again!).

  • javascript.info: Styles and classes
  • MDN: HTMLElement.style
  • w3schools: HTML DOM Element style

posts.title: JavaScript30: Clock
posts.content:
The clock lesson in JavaScript30 guides you through building a digital representation of an analog clock using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The clock that’s created displays the current time via hour, minute and second hands and updates in real-time.

The project is already set up with the following:

  • The HTML structure for the clock, including a container element to hold the clock and a couple of elements to display the hours, minutes, and seconds
  • CSS to style the clock face and hands, along with a background image

I wrote JavaScript code to animate the clock hands and synchronize them to move in real time. It sounds straightforward conceptually, but it was tricky to implement. I had to make use of the `Date` object to get the seconds, minutes and hours needed to animate the clock hands. The hands had to be styled using a transform/rotate to change from rendering horizontally (from 9:00 to 3:00 position) to vertically (12:00 to 6:00 position) and to rotate from their endpoint instead of centerpoint. Wes’ guidance was critical in understanding all of this and solutions to the issues.

Time was updated every second via the `setInterval` function in tandem with a function that used the `Date` object to get the hours, minutes and seconds needed to render the clock hands at the correct positions. CSS transitions were also used to control the animation of the clock hands.

After completing the project, I customized it further by changing the size and color of the clock hands (hours is shortest, minutes is medium and seconds retain their original length). This called for the transform-origins to be changed so the clock hands rendered from their left sides and for removal of the transform rotations from css and placement in the JavaScript file to be calculated there using JavaScript and a new value.

[edit 2023.01.08] I added the date at the bottom, below the digital clock. It shows the weekday, month, date and year, so today, for example, would render “Sun: Jan.08.2023”.

With that done, I changed the colors of clock hands and added a new background, to tie in the new look. I then added a digital clock at the bottom, which updates in real time with the analog clock above it and shows hours, minutes and seconds in the same colors as the matching clock hands.

The main JavaScript features that were used in this project were:

  • functions
  • Date()
    • getSeconds()
    • getMinutes()
    • getHours()
  • element.style.transform()
    • rotate()
  • setInterval()

CSS styles that were used included:

  • transform-origin
  • transform: rotate()
  • transition
  • transition-timing-function: cubic-bezier()
  • transform: translateY()

The formula used to convert the seconds into degrees so that the seconds hand could be properly animated was interesting. It’s (seconds / 60) * 360. Basically, the current number of seconds is divided by 60, which gives a value from 6 degrees ((1 / 60) * 360) to 360 degrees ((60 / 60) * 360). This tells us where to point the seconds hand. The minutes hand used the same formula, and the hours hand divided by 12 instead. Oh, the minimum value was actually 0 degrees (0 / 60), not 6 degrees. The value was further altered to change the starting axis, but the principle is the same.

Here’s a link to my deployed version: https://vish213-clock.netlify.app/

posts.title: The ‘kbd’ and ‘audio’ HTML elements
posts.content:
When I worked on the drum kit project in JavaScript30, I came across two HTML elements that I’ve never used before, the kbd element and the audio element. Here’s a little information about them:

<kbd>

The kbd element in HTML represents user input, typically entered through a keyboard. It’s generally used to indicate that the text it contains is entered by the user or used to illustrate key combinations to execute a command. It is often displayed in a monospace font to make it stand out.

Here’s an example of how the kbd element could be used:

To save the file, press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>S</kbd>

In this example, the kbd element is used to indicate that the user should press the “Ctrl” and “S” keys on their keyboard to save the file.

The kbd element is a inline element, which means it can be used within a block of text and does not take up the full width of the page. It’s often used in conjunction with other elements, such as the code element, to indicate that the text it contains is code or other types of user input.

Note in the above image how the “Ctrl” and “S” are displayed in monotype, and the rest of the text is in the default font.

  • w3schools: HTML kbd tag
  • MDN: <kbd>: The Keyboard input element

<audio>

The audio element in HTML is used to embed audio files into an HTML document. It allows you to add audio to your web page and control how it’s played, such as whether it should start playing automatically or whether it should have controls for the user to start and stop the audio.

Here’s an example of how the audio element can be used:

<audio src="song.mp3" controls></audio>

This will embed an audio file with the URL “song.mp3” into the HTML document and display controls for the user to play and pause the audio.

The audio element supports various attributes that can be used to customize its behavior. For example, the autoplay attribute can be used to make the audio start playing automatically when the page loads, and the loop attribute can be used to make the audio play repeatedly.

Note in the image above that I haven’t linked to an actual audio file, so the displayed duration is 0:00 instead of showing an actual track length.

In the JavaScript30 drum kit project, we manipulated the audio element using JavaScript after grabbing the correct element using a querySelector. One of the things we did was force playback to start from the beginning of a WAV file if that file was called again, using audio.currentTime = 0. Another thing we did was actually start playback using audio.play(). The MDN link below shows attributes and events that can be used to control aspects of the element.

  • w3schools: HTML audio tag
  • MDN: <audio>: The Embed Audio element

posts.title: JavaScript30: Drum kit
posts.content:
I’m working on improving my vanilla JavaScript skills. After finishing Scrimba’s Learn JavaScript for free course two days ago, I decided to start tackling Wes Bos’ JavaScript30. It’s been on my list for at least 3 years, and I started yesterday.

The first project, building a JavaScript drum kit, was really fun. My kids played with it for a while after I built it out, so I lost an hour or so of coding time after it was done, but I gained an hour of downtime for my brain, so it’s a net win.

The goal of the lesson is to create an application that plays a different sound for each drum pad when a corresponding keyboard key is pressed. The application should also include a visual indicator that shows which drum pad or key is being played. The HTML page comes with a “drum kit” rendered onscreen. There are squares that correspond to the middle row of letters on a keyboard running along the middle of the window. So, the letters A, S, D, F, G, H, J, K and L are represented. Each has the name of a drum sound below it. 

Our task is to use JavaScript to connect it to a set of WAV files so that they play when the given key is pressed. This includes adding event listeners to the buttons and the keys on the keyboard, and using the `audio` element to play the corresponding drum sound when a button or key is pressed.

The project is already set up with the following:

  • The HTML structure for the drum pads and the display
  • The CSS styles to render the HTML elements appropriately

I had to write JavaScript code to handle the following:

  • Play the sound for each drum pad when the corresponding key is pressed
  • Update the display to show which drum pad or key is being played
  • Add/remove a “playing” class to the drum pads to create a visual effect when they are played
  • Set up the WAV playback so that it restarts if the same key is pressed multiple times, instead of letting the first trigger of the WAV play all the way through, so a drum pad can be hit repeatedly

The main JavaScript features that were used in this project were:

  • document.querySelector()
  • document.querySelectorAll()
  • .forEach()
  • .addEventListener()
  • .classList.add
  • .classList.remove
  • .propertyName
  • .play()
  • .currentTime
  • event.keyCode (this is deprecated!)

HTML features & elements that were introduced that I haven’t used much before included:

  • data- attributes
  • <kbd> element
  • <audio> element

This was a fun project to start the series off with, and it’s different from every other JavaScript project I’ve done because it connects event listeners to sounds instead of manipulating onscreen elements. I love that change of pace.

I changed the background, but didn’t do much else to make the project different from its typical implementation. After seeing how much the kids liked it, I’m going to take time to record them making some of the weird noises they like to make at their age and then build out a similar project that lets them trigger their own sound effects via keyboard. There are a bunch of things I want to try, to see if I can achieve similar results with a different approach. I’ll post about that after I’ve built it.

Here’s a link to my deployed version: https://vish213-drumkit.netlify.app/

posts.title: Scrimba: Learn JavaScript for free
posts.content:
Happy New Year! It’s been 7 months since I last wrote on this blog. I think that in an older post, I said that I was going through some significant life changes. Well, some of that is settled now, and maybe I’ll discuss it in the future, but for now I’m going to write about a free course I just completed: Learn JavaScript for free, from Scrimba.

I started the course a month ago but didn’t get to work on it every day. The video runtimes total about 8 hours in length, and if you’ve already learned some JavaScript and want a refresher, it’s a fun one. Basics, like variables, math operators, functions and data types like objects and arrays are covered, but they’re all combined with essential DOM manipulation techniques, like getElementById(), createElement(), modifying HTML elements through innerText, textContent and innerHTML and the like.

Several short projects are built throughout the course, which make use of HTML, CSS and JavaScript, with the focus being the latter. Three projects are the focus of guided tutorials and make use of concepts covered in videos. Three others are solo projects which are presented via Figma designs and brief specifications. These include:

  • A passenger counter app (guided tutorial)
  • A basketball scoreboard (solo project)
  • A blackjack game (guided tutorial)
  • A password generator (solo project)
  • A Chrome extension (guided tutorial)
  • A metric/standard unit converter (solo project)

There are three 20-30 minute practice sections with 9 or 10 lessons in each that can be completed after each of the guided tutorial sections. They allow students to practice concepts that were learned in the aforementioned tutorial sections for some extra reps.

It’s been a while since I practiced vanilla JavaScript, and I’ve never felt that my JavaScript skills are especially strong. The majority of the projects I’ve built in the past 18 months used React or Next.js and were largely websites, not applications. This Scrimba course is one step I’ve taken towards strengthening my core JavaScript skills. I’m happy with the results. It’s an incremental set of lessons that drills fundamentals and basic DOM manipulation, which I think are foundational skills for web development.

Just this week, I also joined Scrimba’s Discord server. There are accountability channels in it (#today-i-will and #today-i-did), achievement channels (#i-got-hired and #i-built-this) and help channels dedicated to JavaScript, design, HTML & CSS, React and “other”, among other channels. At any given time, there are hundreds of students logged in.

I really like the platform. I like that the lessons take place in an interactive editor. I also like that concepts are presented in bite-sized chunks and are project-based. I was able to practice more by building my own small projects along the way, based on concepts that we reviewed in each section. One of these was a small project that uses random numbers to display characters in a Street Fighter II splash screen matchup, mainly to entertain my kids. It was based on a random emoji fighter project from the course. Another was an AD&D 2nd Edition character stat roller that also used random numbers for stat generation.

I’m likely going to go through the other free courses on Scrimba and then consider paying for their Frontend Developer Career Path course, which is 75 hours long and includes the lessons from Learn JavaScript for free in its Module 3: Making websites interactive lesson.

posts.title: Building an ecommerce site for The Breast Cancer Comfort Foundation: History
posts.content:
It’s been about 2 months since I last wrote here. In that time, I’ve made a lot of headway with adding a shop to the Breast Cancer Comfort website. I expect to have it completed by the end of the month. Almost all of the functionality is done, with tweaks being made daily. I’m waiting on the team for gift descriptions and to Zoom and pick gift images from the assortment that were sent to me. 

This is my first ecommerce site, and I’m happy that it’s something that I hand-coded instead of using a builder like WordPress. I’ve wanted that experience for some time now.

Last month, I shared a little about it on LinkedIn and got a good response. Between the replies to the post and direct messages, there was a lot of interest in how I built the shop. I informed people there that I would write about the process on the blog and share it, to help other junior developers. I’m starting that now. This post won’t be technical, I’m just going to recap how I found BCC to begin with and what it’s been like working with them. I’ll get into details about the tech and the process in upcoming posts, as I need to organize my thoughts.

Background

In the summer of 2019, I applied for and was accepted into the web development track at Lambda School, an online coding bootcamp. I completed the online precourse, which went through fundamentals of HTML, CSS and JavaScript. I then took an online entrance exam and managed to pass it on my third attempt (so don’t give up if you’re just starting out – try and try again). Lambda’s Web23 cohort started in August with me in tow.

Web23 was a full-time cohort which meant that students were expected to complete the curriculum through weekly sprints over the course of 9 months. After about 2 months, I found that I had woefully underestimated how difficult switching careers and learning these new skills could be. The faint memories of BASIC and Pascal that I had enjoyed in the early 90s couldn’t help to maintain the pace needed to keep up with the rest of the cohort and I ended up switching to part-time and flexing (repeating) some units to really drill certain concepts. The speed and sheer volume of information was overwhelming. 

I’ve said before that I have nothing but respect for students who are able to go through the full-time curriculum. It’s like machine gun fire, with new concepts and projects being shot at you every day and a sprint challenge to demonstrate understanding of all of it at the end of every week. Additionally, my family and I moved from NY to CA in the middle of things (I think I was in the Node/backend portion of the curriculum at that point) and I took several weeks off to complete the move and find somewhere to live. Being a father to two young kids while moving cross-country and being up coding until the small hours of the night, virtually every night, made the experience truly grueling. Ultimately, I graduated in about 18 months, which was standard for part-time students. It was rough.

During either Thanksgiving or winter break in 2019, I discovered The Breast Cancer Comfort Foundation on a website called VolunteerMatch. The site allows non-profit organizations to post volunteer positions for which they need assistance. I was looking to support a cause whose mission aligned with my values, and theirs certainly did. I’ve lost several people who I cared for to various forms of cancer. I also know survivors and marvel at how they embrace life after fighting through the horrors of both the disease and its treatments. I wanted to apply the skills I had been building at bootcamp in a real-world setting and start adding projects to my portfolio. BCC had posted looking for help with their website, and after reviewing it, I decided that I would attempt to help them.

  • Breast Cancer Comfort website v1
  • VolunteerMatch

Version 1 (HTML & CSS)

The demo version of the Breast
Cancer Comfort website (v1)


The original BCC website had been built over what appeared to be 5 years with WordPress. It lacked structure and content. Most of the pages were placeholders.There were pages that were better suited as blog posts, and there were blog posts that should have been pages or sections in other pages (like photo galleries, donor lists and volunteer pages).

I spent a day combing through the site and Googling the organization. During that time, I copied all of the website’s contents into a set of Google docs and organized it. I found articles and videos online that provided more background information about the organization and their founder, Debi Cavolo. She was a nurse and a cancer survivor. Coming from the background of working in IT with nursing homes and then at an EMR for about two decades, I’ve found that I love working with clinicians. My closest mentor was a nurse who I lost to melanoma. She started several companies, including the EMR that I worked for and she fit exceptionally well into a team of techies. It was almost a sign. That weekend, I began to build.

Using the documents I had created, I put together a simple website. I had already organized the information, grouping text together into related categories and cutting parts that were insufficiently fleshed out. I focused on arranging text content first, creating pages and a structure to house all of the information I had gathered and organized. I made a template so that I could build pages rapidly and did my best to ensure that the information on each page was grouped logically. I tried to edit the text to be readable while not erasing the voice it was written in, and to be as grammatically-correct as I could make it without being stiff and overly formal. I enjoy writing and editing, but (as evidenced by this post) I can run on at times.

My budding HTML and CSS skills were put to the test, and by the end of the day I had drafted a simple 5-page website consisting of Home, Boobtique, Donate, Volunteer and Team pages. I looked to other websites with a focus on combating cancer as a source of design inspiration, but did my best to not duplicate them, as the organization needed to be distinct from others in their class. I added color to the site (mainly black and pink) to make it contrast with the existing WordPress implementation and, like many of us, cringed inwardly at my less-than-stellar design skills. 

The next day, I went through each page and made it responsive. I also did my best to apply the smidge of JavaScript that I understood to make a menu for the site. I’ve met a lot of developers who love JavaScript and hate CSS. My skills are more of the opposite. I remember how intimidating it was to puzzle through switching from a navbar to a hamburger menu for mobile devices. In the end, I felt like I had accomplished something. Nowadays, I can build out a responsive navbar using CSS alone (CSS Grid and media breakpoints can accomplish a lot) in addition to falling back to JavaScript to add or subtract classes and styles.

With hope guiding my fingers, I went to the organization’s Facebook page and sent a message to Debi letting her know that I had discovered them through VolunteerMatch, was transitioning from IT to a web development role and had built a proof-of-concept website for them based on their existing WordPress one. I shared the link and said that if they like it, they could keep it, but If they didn’t, it was still a fun exercise for me.

Ultimately, they liked it.

I met with Debi and Susan Weber at their office the next weekend and became their web developer.

  • 2019.12.04 I got my first client project!
  • 2019.12.17 Roadbumps with my first client project

Version 2 (WordPress & Divi)

The 2nd version of the Breast Cancer
Comfort website (WordPress & Divi)


During the first few months of my working with BCC, the organization expanded and took on new volunteers. One of these was a marketing person. He asked me if I could rebuild the site I had implemented using WordPress and Divi, an editor for WP. His rationalization was that if I wasn’t available, no one else knew how to code, and that other people should be able to make website updates without waiting for me. Although I didn’t anticipate a time in which I’d be unduly unavailable, I understood his reasoning and endeavored to learn how to use Divi and rebuild the website. It was hell.

Divi is probably a fine tool for people who don’t code. Using it wasn’t a pleasant experience for me. Everything that I could do in minutes with CSS took hours with Divi. Work multiplied as I had to make two versions of every page or block using their editor so that the site could support both mobile screens and larger ones. Gone was the swiftness of adjusting layouts with media query breakpoints and Flexbox. I no longer had the option to use CSS Grid to create layouts and write quick CSS classes to format images. And the WordPress/Divi combo was laggy.

Building with Divi was slow, and I didn’t like being trapped in the WordPress ecosystem. We had to find plug-ins for everything functional that we wanted to add to the site, like adding a carousel to the homepage. I also didn’t want it to cost the organization any money, if at all possible. The icing on the cake is that in 2020, the marketing director who had joined us had his first baby and left. I inherited Divi as technical debt and spent the rest of the year updating the website with one arm tied behind my back. Content was added to the website in dribs and drabs, but nothing substantial. 

The bootcamp also got intense (hello, data structures & algorithms, Big-O-Notation and the surprise of having to learn Python to solve coding challenges when we had been a JavaScript institution all along) at the same time that we moved cross-country from NY to CA, and some other heavy life events struck that I’m still recovering from. I didn’t do much with the website on a technical level. Updates were mainly text and images. Sometimes, there would be a blog post to publish. At the tail end of 2020, over winter break from the bootcamp, I learned Next.js (the tutorial on their website is fantastic) and built out a website with it that I would redesign and rebuild early in 2021. I used the experience gained from those two projects to guide me with another task I’d been itching to undertake: running as fast away from Divi as humanly possible and rebuilding the site with Next.js.

Version 3 (Next.js)

The current version of the Breast Cancer Comfort website (Next.js)


The next version of the BCC website (see what I did there) is the one that’s still currently in production. I had always planned to rebuild the site using React, but as a React framework, Next is everything React is plus more. Built-in routing, server-side rendering, the Link component, the Image component, component-scoped CSS-in-JS styling, global styles and so much more make it a joy to work with.

With control of the website back in my hands, and the ability to actually write code and marvel that my fledgling JavaScript works, I was able to add functional components to the website that I had really wanted to but couldn’t do with Divi. I added a contact form to the bottom of every page and made it work with Netlify functions to avoid having to build and host a backend. A Google Maps component was embedded with the organization’s location pinned in the middle. I integrated BCC’s Facebook page feed into the news/blog section – all of the blog posts display the feed. I built out an index page of all the blog articles using JavaScript and JSX (it maps through an array of summarized blog data and renders the list) and threw the FB feed on there too for good measure, updated the Supporters page with tiers that were distinguished using Font Awesome icons and did some other fun things. It’s liberating to have the freedom to see a need, imagine a solution and then puzzle out a method to implement it instead of hoping that someone wrote a WP plug-in that can do what I want.

That brings us to the here-and-now.

The big task that I’ve focused on for the past month or so has been learning about ecommerce and building a shop. It’s something I’ve wanted to tackle, but have been intimidated by, for at least a year. I know you other juniors know what I’m talking about. The next few blog posts will dive into the details about how I went about it, but a high-level summary is that I researched a ton of options and eventually went with building my own cart and using Stripe for payment processing and easypost for shipping. Instead of building a Node/Express backend, I went for broke and tried implementing with Netlify serverless functions. So far… it works! Because we don’t rely on a separate, permanent backend, the organization doesn’t have to pay for a server instance that’s constantly live, so we save money. At our size, it meets our needs perfectly. And before the month is through, it should go live, along with the rest of this writeup detailing the process of constructing it.

  • 2021.04.22 April 2021 Update
  • 2021.07.06 Connect a GoDaddy domain to a Netlify website
  • 2022.03.07 Use Font Awesome with Next.js

posts.title: Use Font Awesome with Next.js
posts.content:
We’re three months into 2022 and I haven’t made time to write since November. Life circumstances got in the way, but I might get into that in a later post. Last week, I added support tiers to the Breast Cancer Comfort website. I’ll expand on the format in a future iteration. For now, supporters are distinguished by icons next to their names, with a different one for platinum, gold, silver, bronze and friend levels.

Process

When adding icons to a site, like many, I turn to Font Awesome as my first port-of-call. The BCC website was last built using Next.js, so here’s the procedure I used to make Font Awesome and Next.js work together:

  1. Install the Font Awesome packages into your Next.js project. They’ll come from Fort Awesome – its not a typo. Remember to restart your console after installing the packages.
npm install @fortawesome/fontawesome-svg-core @fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons @fortawesome/react-fontawesome
  1. Edit your page/_app.js file. If you don’t have one yet, go to the “page” folder in your project and create one. Edits made to _app.js apply to all pages in your site, so this will allow Font Awesome icons to be used sitewide.

    We’re doing three things here:
    • importing the CSS that makes the fonts work
    • importing the CSS configuration procedure
    • stopping Font Awesome from automatically adding CSS since its being imported instead
import "@fortawesome/fontawesome-svg-core/styles.css";
import { config } from "@fortawesome/fontawesome-svg-core";
config.autoAddCss = false;

const App = ({ Component, pageProps }) => {
  return <Component {...pageProps} />;
};

export default App;
  1. Use the icon components in your project by importing the FontAwesomeIcon component and any individual icons that are needed on the page.

On the Supporters page of the BCC website, this is imported at the top:

import { FontAwesomeIcon } from "@fortawesome/react-fontawesome"
import { faTrophy, faAward, faMedal, faRibbon } from "@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons"

Further down, in the page, the icons are used like this:

<section className='supporter-list'>
    <h2 className='grey mem-h2'><Tier icon={faTrophy} color='#FFFFFF' />Karen Kostroff, M.D., FACS</h2>
    <h2 className='pink mem-h2'><Tier icon={faAward} color='deeppink' />Beth C. Tortolani Foundation</h2>
    <h2 className='grey mem-h2'><Tier icon={faAward} color='deeppink' />New York Breast Cancer Reconstruction Associates</h2>
    <h2 className='pink mem-h2'><Tier icon={faAward} color='deeppink' />AAA Northeast</h2>
    <h2 className='grey mem-h2'><Tier icon={faAward} color='deeppink' />We Care Fund of the Nassau County Bar Association</h2>
</section>

<Tier> is the presentational component that renders the icon. Its part of the <h2> with the supporter’s name. It takes in two props: icon and color.

const Tier = props => {
    return (
        <span className='award'>
            <FontAwesomeIcon icon={props.icon} style={{ fontsize: "1.5rem", color: props.color}} />
            <style jsx>{`.award {width: 2rem; margin: 0 1.75rem; text-align: center;}`}</style>
        </span>
    )
}

Upcoming changes

Later, I’m going to refactor the <h2> elements into a small component that renders supporters by mapping through them, and I’ll devise a way to alternate background colors for the supporters so that I don’t have to do it manually. My initial attempt (and several modifications) did not render the icons from props, but did fine if they were hard-coded. I’ll figure that out later.

The code block looked like this:

<section className='supporter-list'>
    {supporters.map(supporter =>
        <h2 className={supporter.id % 2 === 0 ? 'grey mem-h2' : 'pink mem-h2'} key={supporter.id}><Tier icon={supporter.icon} color={supporter.color} />{supporter.name}</h2>
    )}
</section>

The data looked like this:

const supporters = [
  {id: 0, name: 'Karen Kostroff, M.D., FACS', icon: {faTrophy}, color: 'FFFFFF'},
  {id: 1, name: 'Beth C. Tortolani Foundation', icon: {faAward}, color: 'deeppink'},
  {id: 2, name: 'New York Breast Cancer Reconstruction Associates', icon: {faAward}, color: 'deeppink'},
  {id: 3, name: 'AAA Northeast', icon: {faAward}, color: 'deeppink'},
  {id: 4, name: 'We Care Fund of the Nassau County Bar Association', icon: {faAward}, color: 'deeppink'},
  // {id: 0, name: '', icon: {}, color: ''},
]

Future supporters might fall into tiers that look like these:

posts.title: Zapier: Authentication Using Session Auth
posts.content:
Building an integration with Zapier starts with authentication. This gives Zapier the ability to use the given user’s credentials to log into an application and access the parts of its API that have been connected to Zapier. For me, this was the hardest part of building an integration between Zapier and our company’s application, AIMM.

Initially, I was only able to get authentication working with a single, hard-coded user. This worked for testing purposes and to let me create Zaps between AIMM and other programs, but it wouldn’t suffice for a production environment in which multiple users from different companies had to log in.

Zapier supports 5 types of authentication: basic auth, session auth, API key auth, OAuth v2 and digest auth. AIMM’s backend already worked using session auth and JavaScript Web Tokens (JWTs) so when I initially met with the more seasoned developers who are building the application, we decided to make use of that with Zapier as well. This guide will walk through how I set up session auth.

Prerequisites

Before you begin configuring Zapier to authenticate to your backend, you need to have some pieces of data:

  1. You need to have the URL to the endpoint that’s used by your application’s backend for authentication and JWT issuance
  2. You need to know how to make a web request for that token (ideally, test this using Postman or Insomnia)
  3. You need to have login credentials to use for authentication

In my case, AIMM’s backend was documented using a tool that was new to me called Swagger. Swagger essentially uses JavaScript on the backend to describe an API’s endpoints which allows it to render a page that displays those endpoints and make test requests to it. Our TL gave me the URL for the endpoint that’s used for authentication and token issuance and told me how to structure the request. I tested it both in Swagger and with Insomnia, to make sure that I could get it to work, because I had to duplicate that process in Zapier.

Below is what it looked like in Insomnia. I’ve removed the endpoint address from the POST request and the credentials from the header. The token itself (access_token) is expired, so that piece of data hasn’t been obscured.

Once you know how to get a token from your application’s backend, you also need to know how to include it in any needed requests to the backend. For example, one of the endpoints in our backend returns an array of all customers. This is used to display a customer list for a given company in our application. When I call that endpoint, I need to include a JWT to confirm that I am, indeed, authorized to exchange data with it.

Different endpoints might have additional requirements when making a request. Some might need additional information in the request header, or might need a JSON object in the request body, so make sure that you know how to properly structure a request to any endpoints you need to connect Zapier with. Test these requests using Postman or Insomnia.

Below is an example of a request in Insomnia to retrieve all customers’ data from AIMM’s API (yes, its a POST request, not a GET request). Note that the request sends JSON in the request body as well as a token in the header.

Armed with this information (the data needed to get a JWT and the data needed to test that token with an API call) we can begin configuring Zapier.

Authentication

A working authentication is the first step in setting up a Zapier integration. The token that’s returned by the API will be used to authorize any API calls made by Zaps once the integration is built. So, what we’re doing here is telling Zapier how to talk to our app’s backend for all future transactions.

The process for setting up authentication is as follows:

  1. Configure authentication fields (essentially, create a form that collects the user’s login information so that Zapier can use it)
  2. Configure a token exchange request (use data from the above authentication fields to connect to an endpoint at the API and retrieve a JWT)
  3. Configure a test request (use the token gained above and successfully call an endpoint to verify that API calls work)
  4. (optional) Set up a connection label (each connection authenticates to the API to get a token; these connections represent different users – I labeled each connection with the name of the company followed by the username so I can tell at a glance who the user is and which company they belong to)
  5. Test the authentication

Let’s walk through it.

Create a new integration

First, if you don’t have a Zapier account, create one. Once you do have one, log in. Next, scroll to the bottom of the website and click on “Developer Platform”. Once that page loads, click on “My Integrations” at the top of the screen.

From here, click on the blue “Start a Zapier Integration” button at the top of the screen and complete the form to set up your integration. All of the fields should be relatively easy to fill out. Their names and purposes are self-explanatory (Name, Description, Homepage URL, Logo, Intended Audience, Role, Category) and have brief descriptions under their labels. The last 3 use drop-downs from which answers can be selected.

Click “Create” when you’re done and you move on to the integration’s configuration section. On the left is a sidebar which displays the selected menu item in the right pane. We want to focus on the “Build” section. We’ll start with “Authentication” and in later posts, we’ll examine “Triggers” and “Actions”.

Configure authentication fields

Click on the blue “Set Up Authentication” button in the right pane. We’re given a list of authentication options that Zapier supports. For our purposes, we’re going to go with Session Auth. Click the blue “Save” button at the bottom of the screen.

We’re now taken to the Session Auth configuration screen. Lets walk through how I set up session authentication for AIMM:

Configure your fields

In the “Step 1” section, we add fields that will be used to create a form which users will fill out with their login information for the application being integrated with Zapier. For AIMM, this required three fields: company name, username and password. There is a 4th field with a value that never changes that we’ll look at in the next step.

Click on “Add Fields” and complete the form to add a new field. There are two field types: field and computed field. We want to use the first one: field. This created user-fillable fields. The second type (computed field) uses data that we pass in, programmatically. I didn’t use it in AIMM’s setup for this step.

  • Label is what the user will see in the form. It shows them the field’s name.
  • Key is what we’ll see when we manipulate the field using JavaScript. Try to match this with the name used by the application’s API.
  • Check the box to mark each field as “required” if it is (all of the ones I used are). 
  • Type is generally going to be string, for which you can just leave the field blank. 
  • Change Type to “Password” if you want typed characters to appear as asterisks onscreen. 

For testing purposes, you can give each field a default value. This will appear in the field’s input box when the login screen is shown to the user, but can be overwritten by typing over it. Click the “Add” button at the bottom of the screen when you’re finished filling in information to setup the current field and then repeat the process for any others that are needed. Once all of the fields that the user needs to fill out are defined, click the blue “Continue” button.

When I was done, my authentication fields looked like this:

Configure a token exchange request

With the login fields defined, we move onto the token exchange request, or Step 2. This is the step for which we gathered information in the prerequisites step, above. For this step, switch to code mode. Refer to the testing that you completed with Postman or Insomnia and modify the provided code in the editor with the settings and parameters that your API needs to get a JWT.

You’ll need your token exchange endpoint, any necessary headers, params and/or JSON for the body. You’ll also need to know what your API calls the token that it produces. Find this in the response body from Insomnia or Postman.

This is what the token exchange code to connect to AIMM looks like:

const options = {
  url: '[removed for privacy, use the URL from Postman/Insomnia]',
  method: 'POST',
  headers: {
    'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded',
    'Accept': 'application/json'
  },
  params: {

  },
  body: {
    'company': bundle.authData.company,
    'username': bundle.authData.username,
    'password': bundle.authData.password,
    'grant_type': 'password',
  }
}

return z.request(options)
  .then((response) => {
    response.throwForStatus();
    const results = response.json;
    console.log(results.access_token);

    return {
      'accessToken': results.access_token,
    };
  });

Note that the AIMM request has no params, but does have headers and a request body. To get the values that the user typed into the form we configured in Step 1, we preface each field name with “bundle.authData.” As mentioned in Step 1, a 4th field is added to the request body here: grant_type. The value of this field is always “password” so we supply it here and the user doesn’t need to know about it.

The name of the JWT returned from AIMM’s API is “access_token”. Your application probably uses a different name, which can be found by examining the response body for your token request in Postman or Insomnia. Return that value in the code for the token exchange request, so that Zapier holds onto it for the next step.

As an aside, Zapier has its own global object, much like “window” or “console” in JavaScript or Node. Its simply called “z”. If you need to run any tests, like console.log, use “z.console.log” to make them work.

Click “Save & Continue”.

Configure a test request & connection label

Now we come to Step 3, in which Zapier will be configured to use data from the user-inputted fields and the token from the previous two steps to call an API endpoint and perform an action. For my test, I called an endpoint in AIMM that returns all of the customers for a given company (the company that the user specified during login).

You can call any endpoint that you’d like from your application’s API as long as you know all of the parameters that it needs to make the call. In my case, no special parameters were needed; no params and no request body. All I needed were the endpoint’s URL and the right headers, which included the JWT gotten from Step 2.

Like before, switch to code mode and modify the pregenerated code to connect to your chosen endpoint. The test endpoint connection used to test AIMM looked like this:

const options = {
   url: '[removed for privacy, use the URL from Postman/Insomnia]',
  method: 'POST',
  headers: {
    'content-type': 'application/json',
    'Authorization': 'Bearer ' + bundle.authData.accessToken,
  },
  params: {

  },
  body: {

  }
}

return z.request(options)
  .then((response) => {
    response.throwForStatus();
    const results = response.json;

    // You can do any parsing you need for results here before returning them

    return results;
  });

Note that the Authorization key in the headers object includes a value which passes in the JWT obtained in Step 2. The format that your application’s API uses to pass in the token might differ from what AIMM’s API uses, so consult the test from Postman or Insomnia to make sure that its correct.

Connection label

There’s an optional step in which the connection label can be named. I switched to code mode here as well and configured the label to include the company name followed by the username of the person whose credentials were being used to make the connection to AIMM. It looks like this:

The field names used by your application will differ, of course, but its probably not a bad idea to configure the label to at least use the username of the person who is authenticating. This is especially useful if several people share the same computer and use it to access the integrated application.

Click “Save & Continue”.

Test your authentication

Finally, we come to the last step: testing the authentication. Here, we’ll use the information that the user provided in the form we created to authenticate to the server and get a JavaScript web token, and then we’ll send that token along in an HTTP request to an endpoint at the API. 

If everything works, we’ll get a successful response and avoid the weeks of self-doubt and dismay that I experienced the first time I tried to make this work. If it doesn’t work, fall back on your troubleshooting skills and examine the error message for clues as to why the world is spinning so uncontrollably off-course.

First, click the blue “Sign in” button in the middle of the section. If you’re re-testing, you can click the drop-down here to add a new account or choose from an existing one. A sign-in screen will appear containing the fields that were defined in Step 1. Fill out the form and submit it. Zapier will take that information and use it to try and get a token from the application’s API. 

If it succeeds, click on “Test Authentication” to use that token to make an API call to the endpoint specified in Step 3. The results, for good or for ill, will be displayed in the Step 4 section.

You should be able to click on the Response, Bundle, HTTP and, in some cases, Console tabs in Step 4 to view their contents. Response will have the server response from the application’s API – or an error.

If things went well, click “Save & Finish”. You’ve done it. You’ve caused Zapier to authenticate to your application’s API and make an HTTP request. Congratulations!

We’ll examine triggers in the next post.
posts.excerpt: Building an integration with Zapier starts with authentication. This gives Zapier the ability to use the given user’s credentials to log into an application and access the parts of its API that have been connected to Zapier. For me, this was the hardest part of building an integration between Zapier and our company’s application, AIMM. […]

posts.title: Introduction to Zapier
posts.content:
As related in previous posts, I started my first developer job about 2 ½ months ago. One of the tasks I was assigned at work was to use an online business automation website called Zapier to connect our application (AIMM) with some other programs, namely QuickBooks Online (QBO) and a whitelabeled CRM called Salespype (CRM).

The initial step was to connect applications so that customer data was able to move from AIMM to the CRM, and then from AIMM to QBO. After that, the next step was to connect the applications in the other direction, so that customers who are first entered in QBO or the CRM could be automatically duplicated in AIMM.

This task took me much longer than it should have. I made progress and got things working in both directions, but authentication wasn’t working the way I needed it to, until today. Previously, I was authenticating using hard-coded data with the same account information instead of dynamic data which would allow different users to log into their AIMM accounts. This allowed me to get everything working, but of course couldn’t work in production because all users would be the same user.

This post is the introduction to a series that shows how I built AIMM’s Zapier integration. Hopefully, it will help other beginner developers who have a similar task. These are the basic steps we’ll look at:

Building a Zapier integration:

  1. Authentication
  2. Triggers
  3. Actions

Setting up Zaps:

  1. Sending customer data from AIMM to the CRM
  2. Sending customer data from AIMM to QBO
  3. Sending customer data from the CRM to AIMM
  4. Sending customer data from QBO to AIMM

Integrations are the term used to describe an application’s connection to Zapier. Integrations are composed of three main parts:

  • Authentication: signing into the given application from Zapier
  • Triggers: conditions that Zapier looks for to let it know to do something
  • Actions: responses to an activated trigger

Triggers and actions are like cause and effect, or like if/then statements. If a trigger happens, then an action (or a series of actions) activates. For example, if a new customer is added in AIMM, then that same customer should be created in QBO and in the CRM.

Authentication, triggers and actions must be set up before users can create Zaps, which are the main focus of Zapier. Zaps are the processes that make use of triggers and actions to let users automate parts of their workflows. 

Different applications have different sets of triggers and actions. Some are more robust than others. For example, right now, AIMM has only one real trigger and set of actions revolving around customer data. Later on, I’m going to add more triggers and actions to accommodate other tasks – for example employee time tracking and updating customers instead of only adding new ones.

My current understanding is that Zaps will mainly make use of typical CRUD operations (create, read, update, delete). At a higher level, there could be other uses I’m not familiar with yet.

Ok. So the next post will move on to authentication.

posts.title: October 2021 Update
posts.content:
Its been a little more than 2 ½ months since I started my first programming job. I’m not really happy with it. The company is essentially a startup. They’ve been around for years as a set of construction and contractor companies, but the software side of the business is relatively new. 

The product I’m working on is called AIMM. Its based on the book Am I Making Any Money from Pacific OutDoor Living and was written by their founder, Terry Morrill. The book contains a system whereby contractors and other types of businesses can determine on an ongoing basis if their business is profitable. It was originally developed as an MS Access application and used internally by POL throughout their operations before they determined that they could market it and make it available to other companies.

Once they started actively developing the program, they moved from Access to Visual Basic. This was a client/server application, and although the system was running, they found that it was difficult to share and grow it, so they hired a team and began porting it to C# and making it a web application. I don’t know the circumstances, but that version was never completed and work began on an updated version using React for the frontend and maintaining the C# backend. That’s the version I’m working with, but not directly on.

Zapier

My main task has been to work on integrating AIMM with other applications using an online business automation tool called Zapier. In a previous post, I explained that Zapier is essentially a site that provides an environment for companies to build API connections to their software. They can then use their application’s Zapier integration to connect it with other programs that are also connected to Zapier. Currently, Zapier has just shy of 4,000 programs connected to them, so there’s a wide assortment of available applications to connect with.

The benefit of this is that custom connections don’t need to be written for each program that an application needs to connect to. Companies don’t need to coordinate and work together to build out interfaces. Instead, they build a single interface with Zapier and can then send data back and forth with any other application in Zapier’s ecosphere.

Connectivity varies between programs. Some companies provide robust API connections, and others provide minimal connections. I’ve been working on connecting AIMM with QuickBooks Online and with a whitelabeled CRM called Salespype. Its been demoralizing.

The development team has shared that AIMM’s backend was not designed well. Many of the developers have voiced concerns about how it operates, and after working with it a little myself, I concur with their assessment of the API being cryptic and difficult to use. There’s a planned rewrite of the API in Node & Express, which I’ll be happy to see. The goal is to make it simpler by removing many deprecated endpoints, to enhance security and to make it RESTful. There are other issues that a rewrite aims to correct as well, but they’re security-related, so I won’t go into them.

I’ve had a lot of trouble with authentication between Zapier and AIMM. Authentication is the first step in building an integration. Once that’s set up, other steps which allow data to be exchanged and actions to happen can be built out. I was able to configure outbound data transfer from AIMM to both QBO and Salespype a few weeks ago, but it took me even longer to get the reverse operations working. We do have bidirectional functionality now, but its in its infancy, with only customer data being shared between all three applications. There’s a lot more to connect.

Authentication is also not working as smoothly as I’d like it to. I can’t elaborate on that, for security reasons, but I’m currently trying to make it work the way that it should, and its not clear to me whether the fault is with how I’ve configured Zapier or with our API.

User Guide

Another task I’ve been working on is writing the user guide for AIMM. I’m learning the program as I go, and I have a lot to cover, so I’m not happy with my progress in this arena either. Over the last three days, I wrote out instructions in the guide to walk end users through connecting AIMM with QBO and with the CRM. Ultimately, I think I’m going to end up personally setting up a lot of these connections though. There are some steps, especially where data has to be reformatted using tools provided by Zapier, that will be beyond the ability (and patience) of typical users.

On the plus side, I’ve been introduced to readme.io/readme.com, which I’m using to write the user guide, and I like it. It uses Markdown and some drag-and-drop components to create pages and has a table of contents and a page-specific contents section that automatically updates as pages and content are added.

Dissatisfaction

My main unhappiness at this job stems from two issues: (1) I don’t know this industry or application so my output is greatly slowed, and (2) I’m not doing as much coding as I had expected. The former issue can be overcome with time and familiarity with the program, but its not proceeding at a pace that I’d like. The latter issue is also something that can be overcome as my tasks change, but I don’t see it happening quickly as I’m quite literally writing a book.

I’ve written some code and made commits and pull requests to the application’s repo on GitHub. They were merged and are in the updated v1.1 of the program, but since I’m mainly working with Zapier and on the user guide, I’m not using my coding skills at the frequency that I’d expected when I joined the company.

I’ve written some JavaScript in Zapier’s environment as well, but they use an older version of JavaScript (its not ES6) and I’ve largely been finding my way in the dark there. Some other developers have looked at Zapier with me, to help solve authentication issues and initial data transfer concerns, but for the most part, I’m swimming in uncharted seas and not having a great time doing it.

I’ve also been unable to dedicate the time that I’d like to on outside projects. That’s been a big letdown for me. I want to work on projects for my own web development company. I want to finish building out an ecommerce module for Breast Cancer Comfort’s website. There are a few other projects that I’d like to complete, and I really want to dive more deeply into Next.js, especially with v12 just having been released this week, but I’ve been completely drained of energy every weeknight, and I’ve been spending as much time with my kids as I can on the weekends.

I can see from writing this that I need to improve my time management skills.

Upcoming

Anyway, this has been something of a downer of a blog post. Hopefully, upcoming ones won’t be the same. I plan on writing a series of posts going through building Zapier integrations, to help other new developers navigate that process. I also want to write out a series of posts analyzing a fantastic ecommerce course I was working through, but stalled due to work. It uses Next.js, Shopify’s Storefront API, GraphQL and Tailwind CSS to make websites that are fast and responsive due to Next.js and business-ready thanks to Shopify.
